title: How to Make Christmas Muffins

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and line a muffin tin.
steps.description: Get out 2 12-hole muffin tins and put liners into 16 of the cavities. If you prefer, grease or spray the inside of the tin with baking spray or butter. Set the tins aside while you make the muffin batter.

steps.headline: Whisk the flour, baking soda, salt, and spices for 30 seconds.
steps.description: Put 2 3/4 cups (343 g) of all-purpose flour into a bowl and add 2 1/2 teaspoons (11.5 g) of baking soda, 1 tablespoon plus 1/2 teaspoon (7 g) of ground ginger, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of ground cinnamon, 1/8 teaspoon (0.25 g) of ground cloves, and 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of salt. Whisk for about 30 seconds, so the dry ingredients combine.

steps.headline: Beat the butter and sugar in a separate bowl for 3 to 4 minutes.
steps.description: Get out a large mixing bowl and put 1/2 cup (113 g) of room temperature butter into it along with 1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons (125 g) of granulated sugar. Use a stand or hand mixer to beat the mixture on medium speed until it's light and pale. Stop the mixer and scrape down the sides of the bowl a few times. If you want to mix the butter and sugar by hand, use a wooden spoon and beat the mixture for 5 to 6 minutes.

steps.headline: Mix the eggs and molasses into the butter mixture.
steps.description: Turn off the mixer and add 2 large eggs to the bowl with the creamed butter and sugar. Turn on the mixer to low and beat the eggs until they're combined. Then beat in 3/4 cup (245 g) of molasses until it's incorporated. You can use light or dark molasses. If you prefer a spicier gingerbread, choose the dark molasses.

steps.headline: Add the dry ingredients and water in alternating additions.
steps.description: Mix 1/2 of the dry ingredients into the bowl with the butter mixture. Slowly beat in 1 ⁄3 cups (320 ml) of cold water and then mix in the rest of the dry ingredients. Stop mixing once the dry ingredients are incorporated. If you overmix the muffin batter, the muffins will be tough.

steps.headline: Fill 16 muffin liners and bake the muffins for 25 minutes.
steps.description: Spoon or scoop the batter into 16 muffin tin cavities and then put the tins into the preheated oven. Bake the muffins until a toothpick or skewer comes out clean when you insert it in the center of a muffin.Variation: To make a spiced crumble topping instead of icing, mix together 1 cup (125 g) of flour, 1/2 cup (100 g) of brown sugar, 2 tablespoons (25 g) of granulated sugar, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of ginger, 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of cinnamon, a pinch of salt, and 1/2 cup (113 g) of melted butter until it's crumbly. Scatter the streusel evenly over the muffins before baking them. If the toothpick comes out with batter on it, put the muffins back in the oven for another 3 minutes before checking them again.

steps.headline: Remove the muffins and cool them for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Set the muffin tins on a wire rack and leave the muffins to cool for 10 minutes before you tip the muffins out onto the rack to finish cooling. Then serve or decorate the muffins. Store the leftover muffins in an airtight container for up to 3 to 4 days.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 375 °F (191 °C) and line a muffin tin.
steps.description: Get out 2 12-hole muffin tins and line each muffin cavity. If you prefer, spray the inside of the tin with baking spray instead of using muffin liners. Then set the pans aside while you make the batter. If you only have 1 muffin tin, bake 1 dozen muffins, remove the muffins, and let the pan cool before baking the remaining 8 muffins.

steps.headline: Toss the cranberries with the granulated sugar.
steps.description: Put 2 cups (200 g) of chopped fresh cranberries into a bowl and add 1/2 cup (100 g) of granulated sugar. Use a spoon to stir the cranberries until they're coated with the sugar. Then set the cranberries aside.Tip: Cranberries can be tricky to chop since they roll around. Instead of chopping them by hand, consider pulsing them 2 to 3 times in a blender or food processor.

steps.headline: Put the remaining ingredients into a large bowl.
steps.description:
Place 1 1/2 cups (187 g) of all-purpose flour and 1 1/2 cups (194 g) of whole-wheat flour into a bowl with 1/2 cup (170 g) of honey, 2 large eggs, 1 ⁄2 cups (350 ml) of eggnog, ⁄3 cup (160 ml) of coconut oil, 1/2 cup (65 g) of chopped walnuts, and the following dry ingredients:
1 tablespoon (12 g) of baking powder
1 teaspoon (5 g) of salt
1 1/2 teaspoons (3 g) of cinnamon
1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground nutmeg

steps.headline: Stir the batter until it's just combined.
steps.description: Use a rubber spatula to mix the ingredients until the dry ingredients are absorbed and the batter is smooth. Ensure that you don't stir it too long after this or the muffins will be tough.

steps.headline: Fold in the sugared cranberries.
steps.description: Add the sugared cranberries and any juice that's at the bottom of the bowl to the muffin batter. Gently fold the batter up and over the cranberries until they're incorporated. If you'd like to add an herbal flavor, include 1 tablespoon (2 g) of minced fresh rosemary when you add the sugared cranberries.

steps.headline: Fill 20 of the muffin liners and bake the muffins for 15 to 20 minutes.
steps.description: Use a spoon or cookie scoop to divide the batter between 20 of the cavities in the muffin tins. Then bake the muffins in the preheated oven for 15 to 20 minutes. To test if the muffins have finished baking, insert a toothpick or skewer into a muffin. If it comes out clean, they're done. If not, bake them for 2 more minutes and check again.

steps.headline: Serve the muffins warm or cool.
steps.description: Remove the muffins and turn them out onto a wire rack. You can serve the muffins when they're cool enough to handle but still warm. If you prefer, let the muffins cool completely and then dust them with powdered sugar before serving. Put the leftover muffins in an airtight container and keep them at room temperature for up to 3 to 4 days.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 355 °F (179 °C) and line a muffin tin.
steps.description: Get out a 12-hole muffin tin and put muffin liners into each cavity. If you don't want to use muffin liners, you can spray the inside of the tin with baking spray. Set the pan aside while you prepare the muffin batter.

steps.headline: Put the butter, sugar, eggs, flour, baking powder, and spices in a bowl.
steps.description: Place 3/4 cup (175 g) of softened butter into a large mixing bowl along with 3/4 cup (175 g) of brown sugar, 3 eggs, 1 2/3 cups (175 g) of self-rising flour, 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of salt, 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of baking powder, and 2 tablespoons (15 g) of ground mixed spice.Homemade Mixed Spice:1/2 tablespoon (3 g) of ground cinnamon1 teaspoon (2 g) of ground allspice1 teaspoon (2 g) of ground nutmeg1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground cloves1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground ginger1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground coriander1/4 teaspoon of (0.5 g) of ground mace

steps.headline: Beat the ingredients in the mixing bowl for 3 to 4 minutes.
steps.description: Use a stand or hand mixer to combine the ingredients on medium speed. Keep beating until the mixture is pale and creamy. You may need to stop and scrape down the sides of the bowl occasionally. If you prefer to beat the mixture by hand, use a wooden spoon and beat the mixture for 5 to 6 minutes.

steps.headline: Fold in the dried mixed fruit and brandy or orange juice.
steps.description: Add 2/3 cup (115 g) of mixed dried fruit and 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of brandy or orange juice to the batter in the mixing bowl. Use a spatula to fold in the fruit and liquid until they're incorporated. To fold, use a twisting motion with your wrist to bring the batter up and over the fruit. Keep doing this gently to keep as much air in the batter as possible. This will make the muffins light.

steps.headline: Divide the batter in the tin and bake the muffins for 25 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: Use a cookie scoop or large spoon to scoop the batter into the prepared muffin tin. The batter should fill all 12 muffin cavities. Then put the tin in the preheated oven and bake the muffins until they're cooked throughout. To test if the muffins are done, insert a toothpick or skewer into the center of a muffin. The muffins are finished if the tester comes out clean. If not, bake the muffins for another 2 minutes and check again.

steps.headline: Cool the muffins completely.
steps.description: Remove the tin from the oven and let the muffins cool for 5 minutes in the tin. Then turn them out onto a wire rack and leave them until they're completely cooled. Then you can ice or decorate the muffins.Did You Know? It's important to cool the muffins before covering them with icing. If you spread icing on warm muffins, the icing will slide off or the muffins will absorb it. If you store the muffins ahead of time, wait to put the decorations on the icing or they could discolor it. Store the leftover muffins in an airtight container for up to 3 to 4 days.

steps.headline: Whisk the powdered sugar with lemon juice to make simple icing.
steps.description: Put 1 3/4 cups (292 g) of powdered sugar into a bowl and pour in 5 tablespoons (74 ml) of lemon juice. Whisk until the powdered sugar dissolves and drizzle about 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of icing over the top of each muffin. Then let the muffins sit for a few minutes before serving them so the icing sets up.Did You Know? If you plan on decorating the muffins with sprinkles or candy, you'll need to put icing on them in order for the decorations to stick. If you prefer, substitute orange juice for the lemon juice.

steps.headline: Arrange glacé cherries and candy holly on the muffins for a festive look.
steps.description: Set the muffins on a serving platter and spread some of the icing on top of each muffin. Then place a glacé cherry and candy holly leaf on top of each just before serving. Glacé cherries and candy holly will make the muffins look like miniature Christmas cakes.

steps.headline: Scatter sprinkles over the icing for a sparkly effect.
steps.description: Once you've covered the muffins with icing, shake your favorite sprinkles over each muffin. Use a single color or a combination of Christmas colors, such as red, green, and silver. You can also find sprinkles that are in Christmas shapes. For example, use star or Christmas tree shaped sprinkles.

steps.headline: Dust the muffins with powdered sugar to look like snow.
steps.description: If you don't want to top the muffins with icing, put some powdered sugar into a sifter. Gently shake the powdered sugar so it falls on top of the muffins. It's important to do this after the muffins have cooled or they'll absorb the powdered sugar.

steps.headline: Finished.

text:
Gingerbread Muffins Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and line a muffin tin. Get out 2 12-hole muffin tins and put liners into 16 of the cavities. If you prefer, grease or spray the inside of the tin with baking spray or butter. Set the tins aside while you make the muffin batter. Whisk the flour, baking soda, salt, and spices for 30 seconds. Put 2 3/4 cups (343 g) of all-purpose flour into a bowl and add 2 1/2 teaspoons (11.5 g) of baking soda, 1 tablespoon plus 1/2 teaspoon (7 g) of ground ginger, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of ground cinnamon, 1/8 teaspoon (0.25 g) of ground cloves, and 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of salt. Whisk for about 30 seconds, so the dry ingredients combine. Beat the butter and sugar in a separate bowl for 3 to 4 minutes. Get out a large mixing bowl and put 1/2 cup (113 g) of room temperature butter into it along with 1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons (125 g) of granulated sugar. Use a stand or hand mixer to beat the mixture on medium speed until it's light and pale. Stop the mixer and scrape down the sides of the bowl a few times. If you want to mix the butter and sugar by hand, use a wooden spoon and beat the mixture for 5 to 6 minutes. Mix the eggs and molasses into the butter mixture. Turn off the mixer and add 2 large eggs to the bowl with the creamed butter and sugar. Turn on the mixer to low and beat the eggs until they're combined. Then beat in 3/4 cup (245 g) of molasses until it's incorporated. You can use light or dark molasses. If you prefer a spicier gingerbread, choose the dark molasses. Add the dry ingredients and water in alternating additions. Mix 1/2 of the dry ingredients into the bowl with the butter mixture. Slowly beat in 1 ⁄3 cups (320 ml) of cold water and then mix in the rest of the dry ingredients. Stop mixing once the dry ingredients are incorporated. If you overmix the muffin batter, the muffins will be tough. Fill 16 muffin liners and bake the muffins for 25 minutes. Spoon or scoop the batter into 16 muffin tin cavities and then put the tins into the preheated oven. Bake the muffins until a toothpick or skewer comes out clean when you insert it in the center of a muffin.Variation: To make a spiced crumble topping instead of icing, mix together 1 cup (125 g) of flour, 1/2 cup (100 g) of brown sugar, 2 tablespoons (25 g) of granulated sugar, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of ginger, 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of cinnamon, a pinch of salt, and 1/2 cup (113 g) of melted butter until it's crumbly. Scatter the streusel evenly over the muffins before baking them. If the toothpick comes out with batter on it, put the muffins back in the oven for another 3 minutes before checking them again. Remove the muffins and cool them for 10 minutes. Set the muffin tins on a wire rack and leave the muffins to cool for 10 minutes before you tip the muffins out onto the rack to finish cooling. Then serve or decorate the muffins. Store the leftover muffins in an airtight container for up to 3 to 4 days. Healthy Cranberry Eggnog Muffins Preheat the oven to 375 °F (191 °C) and line a muffin tin. Get out 2 12-hole muffin tins and line each muffin cavity. If you prefer, spray the inside of the tin with baking spray instead of using muffin liners. Then set the pans aside while you make the batter. If you only have 1 muffin tin, bake 1 dozen muffins, remove the muffins, and let the pan cool before baking the remaining 8 muffins. Toss the cranberries with the granulated sugar. Put 2 cups (200 g) of chopped fresh cranberries into a bowl and add 1/2 cup (100 g) of granulated sugar. Use a spoon to stir the cranberries until they're coated with the sugar. Then set the cranberries aside.Tip: Cranberries can be tricky to chop since they roll around. Instead of chopping them by hand, consider pulsing them 2 to 3 times in a blender or food processor. Put the remaining ingredients into a large bowl. Place 1 1/2 cups (187 g) of all-purpose flour and 1 1/2 cups (194 g) of whole-wheat flour into a bowl with 1/2 cup (170 g) of honey, 2 large eggs, 1 ⁄2 cups (350 ml) of eggnog, ⁄3 cup (160 ml) of coconut oil, 1/2 cup (65 g) of chopped walnuts, and the following dry ingredients:
1 tablespoon (12 g) of baking powder
1 teaspoon (5 g) of salt
1 1/2 teaspoons (3 g) of cinnamon
1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground nutmeg Stir the batter until it's just combined. Use a rubber spatula to mix the ingredients until the dry ingredients are absorbed and the batter is smooth. Ensure that you don't stir it too long after this or the muffins will be tough. Fold in the sugared cranberries. Add the sugared cranberries and any juice that's at the bottom of the bowl to the muffin batter. Gently fold the batter up and over the cranberries until they're incorporated. If you'd like to add an herbal flavor, include 1 tablespoon (2 g) of minced fresh rosemary when you add the sugared cranberries. Fill 20 of the muffin liners and bake the muffins for 15 to 20 minutes. Use a spoon or cookie scoop to divide the batter between 20 of the cavities in the muffin tins. Then bake the muffins in the preheated oven for 15 to 20 minutes. To test if the muffins have finished baking, insert a toothpick or skewer into a muffin. If it comes out clean, they're done. If not, bake them for 2 more minutes and check again. Serve the muffins warm or cool. Remove the muffins and turn them out onto a wire rack. You can serve the muffins when they're cool enough to handle but still warm. If you prefer, let the muffins cool completely and then dust them with powdered sugar before serving. Put the leftover muffins in an airtight container and keep them at room temperature for up to 3 to 4 days. Christmas Cake Muffins Preheat the oven to 355 °F (179 °C) and line a muffin tin. Get out a 12-hole muffin tin and put muffin liners into each cavity. If you don't want to use muffin liners, you can spray the inside of the tin with baking spray. Set the pan aside while you prepare the muffin batter. Put the butter, sugar, eggs, flour, baking powder, and spices in a bowl. Place 3/4 cup (175 g) of softened butter into a large mixing bowl along with 3/4 cup (175 g) of brown sugar, 3 eggs, 1 2/3 cups (175 g) of self-rising flour, 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of salt, 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of baking powder, and 2 tablespoons (15 g) of ground mixed spice.Homemade Mixed Spice:1/2 tablespoon (3 g) of ground cinnamon1 teaspoon (2 g) of ground allspice1 teaspoon (2 g) of ground nutmeg1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground cloves1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground ginger1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground coriander1/4 teaspoon of (0.5 g) of ground mace Beat the ingredients in the mixing bowl for 3 to 4 minutes. Use a stand or hand mixer to combine the ingredients on medium speed. Keep beating until the mixture is pale and creamy. You may need to stop and scrape down the sides of the bowl occasionally. If you prefer to beat the mixture by hand, use a wooden spoon and beat the mixture for 5 to 6 minutes. Fold in the dried mixed fruit and brandy or orange juice. Add 2/3 cup (115 g) of mixed dried fruit and 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of brandy or orange juice to the batter in the mixing bowl. Use a spatula to fold in the fruit and liquid until they're incorporated. To fold, use a twisting motion with your wrist to bring the batter up and over the fruit. Keep doing this gently to keep as much air in the batter as possible. This will make the muffins light. Divide the batter in the tin and bake the muffins for 25 to 30 minutes. Use a cookie scoop or large spoon to scoop the batter into the prepared muffin tin. The batter should fill all 12 muffin cavities. Then put the tin in the preheated oven and bake the muffins until they're cooked throughout. To test if the muffins are done, insert a toothpick or skewer into the center of a muffin. The muffins are finished if the tester comes out clean. If not, bake the muffins for another 2 minutes and check again. Cool the muffins completely. Remove the tin from the oven and let the muffins cool for 5 minutes in the tin. Then turn them out onto a wire rack and leave them until they're completely cooled. Then you can ice or decorate the muffins.Did You Know? It's important to cool the muffins before covering them with icing. If you spread icing on warm muffins, the icing will slide off or the muffins will absorb it. If you store the muffins ahead of time, wait to put the decorations on the icing or they could discolor it. Store the leftover muffins in an airtight container for up to 3 to 4 days. Decorating the Muffins Whisk the powdered sugar with lemon juice to make simple icing. Put 1 3/4 cups (292 g) of powdered sugar into a bowl and pour in 5 tablespoons (74 ml) of lemon juice. Whisk until the powdered sugar dissolves and drizzle about 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of icing over the top of each muffin. Then let the muffins sit for a few minutes before serving them so the icing sets up.Did You Know? If you plan on decorating the muffins with sprinkles or candy, you'll need to put icing on them in order for the decorations to stick. If you prefer, substitute orange juice for the lemon juice. Arrange glacé cherries and candy holly on the muffins for a festive look. Set the muffins on a serving platter and spread some of the icing on top of each muffin. Then place a glacé cherry and candy holly leaf on top of each just before serving. Glacé cherries and candy holly will make the muffins look like miniature Christmas cakes. Scatter sprinkles over the icing for a sparkly effect. Once you've covered the muffins with icing, shake your favorite sprinkles over each muffin. Use a single color or a combination of Christmas colors, such as red, green, and silver. You can also find sprinkles that are in Christmas shapes. For example, use star or Christmas tree shaped sprinkles. Dust the muffins with powdered sugar to look like snow. If you don't want to top the muffins with icing, put some powdered sugar into a sifter. Gently shake the powdered sugar so it falls on top of the muffins. It's important to do this after the muffins have cooled or they'll absorb the powdered sugar. Finished.
sentences: Gingerbread Muffins Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and line a muffin tin.
Get out 2 12-hole muffin tins and put liners into 16 of the cavities.
If you prefer, grease or spray the inside of the tin with baking spray or butter.
Set the tins aside while you make the muffin batter.
Whisk the flour, baking soda, salt, and spices for 30 seconds.

Put 2 3/4 cups (343 g) of all-purpose flour into a bowl and add 2 1/2 teaspoons (11.5 g) of baking soda, 1 tablespoon plus 1/2 teaspoon (7 g) of ground ginger, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of ground cinnamon, 1/8 teaspoon (0.25 g) of ground cloves, and 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of salt.
Whisk for about 30 seconds, so the dry ingredients combine.
Beat the butter and sugar in a separate bowl for 3 to 4 minutes.
Get out a large mixing bowl and put 1/2 cup (113 g) of room temperature butter into it along with 1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons (125 g) of granulated sugar.
Use a stand or hand mixer to beat the mixture on medium speed until it's light and pale.
Stop the mixer and scrape down the sides of the bowl a few times.
If you want to mix the butter and sugar by hand, use a wooden spoon and beat the mixture for 5 to 6 minutes.
Mix the eggs and molasses into the butter mixture.
Turn off the mixer and add 2 large eggs to the bowl with the creamed butter and sugar.
Turn on the mixer to low and beat the eggs until they're combined.
Then beat in 3/4 cup (245 g) of molasses until it's incorporated.
You can use light or dark molasses.
If you prefer a spicier gingerbread, choose the dark molasses.
Add the dry ingredients and water in alternating additions.
Mix 1/2 of the dry ingredients into the bowl with the butter mixture.
Slowly beat in 1 ⁄3 cups (320 ml) of cold water and then mix in the rest of the dry ingredients.
Stop mixing once the dry ingredients are incorporated.
If you overmix the muffin batter, the muffins will be tough.
Fill 16 muffin liners and bake the muffins for 25 minutes.
Spoon or scoop the batter into 16 muffin tin cavities and then put the tins into the preheated oven.

Bake the muffins until a toothpick or skewer comes out clean when you insert it in the center of a muffin.Variation: To make a spiced crumble topping instead of icing, mix together 1 cup (125 g) of flour, 1/2 cup (100 g) of brown sugar, 2 tablespoons (25 g) of granulated sugar, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of ginger, 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of cinnamon, a pinch of salt, and 1/2 cup (113 g) of melted butter until it's crumbly.
Scatter the streusel evenly over the muffins before baking them.
If the toothpick comes out with batter on it, put the muffins back in the oven for another 3 minutes before checking them again.
Remove the muffins and cool them for 10 minutes.
Set the muffin tins on a wire rack and leave the muffins to cool for 10 minutes before you tip the muffins out onto the rack to finish cooling.
Then serve or decorate the muffins.
Store the leftover muffins in an airtight container for up to 3 to 4 days.
Healthy Cranberry Eggnog Muffins Preheat the oven to 375 °F (191 °C) and line a muffin tin.
Get out 2 12-hole muffin tins and line each muffin cavity.
If you prefer, spray the inside of the tin with baking spray instead of using muffin liners.
Then set the pans aside while you make the batter.
If you only have 1 muffin tin, bake 1 dozen muffins, remove the muffins, and let the pan cool before baking the remaining 8 muffins.
Toss the cranberries with the granulated sugar.
Put 2 cups (200 g) of chopped fresh cranberries into a bowl and add 1/2 cup (100 g) of granulated sugar.
Use a spoon to stir the cranberries until they're coated with the sugar.
Then set the cranberries aside.Tip: Cranberries can be tricky to chop since they roll around.
Instead of chopping them by hand, consider pulsing them 2 to 3 times in a blender or food processor.
Put the remaining ingredients into a large bowl.

Place 1 1/2 cups (187 g) of all-purpose flour and 1 1/2 cups (194 g) of whole-wheat flour into a bowl with 1/2 cup (170 g) of honey, 2 large eggs, 1 ⁄2 cups (350 ml) of eggnog, ⁄3 cup (160 ml) of coconut oil, 1/2 cup (65 g) of chopped walnuts, and the following dry ingredients:
1 tablespoon (12 g) of baking powder
1 teaspoon (5 g) of salt
1 1/2 teaspoons (3 g) of cinnamon
1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground nutmeg Stir the batter until it's just combined.
Use a rubber spatula to mix the ingredients until the dry ingredients are absorbed and the batter is smooth.
Ensure that you don't stir it too long after this or the muffins will be tough.
Fold in the sugared cranberries.
Add the sugared cranberries and any juice that's at the bottom of the bowl to the muffin batter.
Gently fold the batter up and over the cranberries until they're incorporated.
If you'd like to add an herbal flavor, include 1 tablespoon (2 g) of minced fresh rosemary when you add the sugared cranberries.
Fill 20 of the muffin liners and bake the muffins for 15 to 20 minutes.
Use a spoon or cookie scoop to divide the batter between 20 of the cavities in the muffin tins.
Then bake the muffins in the preheated oven for 15 to 20 minutes.
To test if the muffins have finished baking, insert a toothpick or skewer into a muffin.
If it comes out clean, they're done.
If not, bake them for 2 more minutes and check again.
Serve the muffins warm or cool.
Remove the muffins and turn them out onto a wire rack.
You can serve the muffins when they're cool enough to handle but still warm.
If you prefer, let the muffins cool completely and then dust them with powdered sugar before serving.
Put the leftover muffins in an airtight container and keep them at room temperature for up to 3 to 4 days.
Christmas Cake Muffins Preheat the oven to 355 °F (179 °C) and line a muffin tin.
Get out a 12-hole muffin tin and put muffin liners into each cavity.
If you don't want to use muffin liners, you can spray the inside of the tin with baking spray.
Set the pan aside while you prepare the muffin batter.
Put the butter, sugar, eggs, flour, baking powder, and spices in a bowl.

Place 3/4 cup (175 g) of softened butter into a large mixing bowl along with 3/4 cup (175 g) of brown sugar, 3 eggs, 1 2/3 cups (175 g) of self-rising flour, 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of salt, 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of baking powder, and 2 tablespoons (15 g) of ground mixed spice.Homemade Mixed Spice:1/2 tablespoon (3 g) of ground cinnamon1 teaspoon (2 g) of ground allspice1 teaspoon (2 g) of ground nutmeg1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground cloves1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground ginger1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground coriander1/4 teaspoon of (0.5 g) of ground mace Beat the ingredients in the mixing bowl for 3 to 4 minutes.
Use a stand or hand mixer to combine the ingredients on medium speed.
Keep beating until the mixture is pale and creamy.
You may need to stop and scrape down the sides of the bowl occasionally.
If you prefer to beat the mixture by hand, use a wooden spoon and beat the mixture for 5 to 6 minutes.
Fold in the dried mixed fruit and brandy or orange juice.
Add 2/3 cup (115 g) of mixed dried fruit and 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of brandy or orange juice to the batter in the mixing bowl.
Use a spatula to fold in the fruit and liquid until they're incorporated.
To fold, use a twisting motion with your wrist to bring the batter up and over the fruit.
Keep doing this gently to keep as much air in the batter as possible.
This will make the muffins light.
Divide the batter in the tin and bake the muffins for 25 to 30 minutes.
Use a cookie scoop or large spoon to scoop the batter into the prepared muffin tin.
The batter should fill all 12 muffin cavities.
Then put the tin in the preheated oven and bake the muffins until they're cooked throughout.
To test if the muffins are done, insert a toothpick or skewer into the center of a muffin.
The muffins are finished if the tester comes out clean.
If not, bake the muffins for another 2 minutes and check again.
Cool the muffins completely.
Remove the tin from the oven and let the muffins cool for 5 minutes in the tin.
Then turn them out onto a wire rack and leave them until they're completely cooled.
Then you can ice or decorate the muffins.Did You Know?
It's important to cool the muffins before covering them with icing.
If you spread icing on warm muffins, the icing will slide off or the muffins will absorb it.
If you store the muffins ahead of time, wait to put the decorations on the icing or they could discolor it.
Store the leftover muffins in an airtight container for up to 3 to 4 days.
Decorating the Muffins Whisk the powdered sugar with lemon juice to make simple icing.
Put 1 3/4 cups (292 g) of powdered sugar into a bowl and pour in 5 tablespoons (74 ml) of lemon juice.
Whisk until the powdered sugar dissolves and drizzle about 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of icing over the top of each muffin.
Then let the muffins sit for a few minutes before serving them so the icing sets up.Did You Know?
If you plan on decorating the muffins with sprinkles or candy, you'll need to put icing on them in order for the decorations to stick.
If you prefer, substitute orange juice for the lemon juice.
Arrange glacé cherries and candy holly on the muffins for a festive look.
Set the muffins on a serving platter and spread some of the icing on top of each muffin.
Then place a glacé cherry and candy holly leaf on top of each just before serving.
Glacé cherries and candy holly will make the muffins look like miniature Christmas cakes.
Scatter sprinkles over the icing for a sparkly effect.
Once you've covered the muffins with icing, shake your favorite sprinkles over each muffin.
Use a single color or a combination of Christmas colors, such as red, green, and silver.
You can also find sprinkles that are in Christmas shapes.
For example, use star or Christmas tree shaped sprinkles.
Dust the muffins with powdered sugar to look like snow.
If you don't want to top the muffins with icing, put some powdered sugar into a sifter.
Gently shake the powdered sugar so it falls on top of the muffins.
It's important to do this after the muffins have cooled or they'll absorb the powdered sugar.
Finished.
